summary: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Louisiana today announced criminal charges against a St. John the Baptist Parish firefighter who was charged with negligent homicide following an automobile accident.  According to the SEC's complaint, on August 28, 2016, William Beal was driving a 2003 Chevrolet Silverado party bus with approximately 40 passengers when he lost control of the bus and almost hit three firemen. The complaint alleges that after the accident, defendant failed to slow the bus down and attempted to cut over in front of the firemen, who were standing next to the bus. The SEC alleges that the bus then clipped the right front of a fire truck that was blocking the right lane of the interstate.  The complaint further alleges that when the bus driver saw the crash, he immediately jumped out of the vehicle and ran to the fireman's truck.  After the bus hit the guardrail, Mr. Beal and his co-worker, Gerard Breaux, allegedly tried to stop the bus, but the bus did not stop until it was too late to avoid the collision.  As alleged in the complaint, after the wreck, defendant began to drive the bus at a high rate of speed and when he stopped, he cut over into the back of a red Toyota Camry. The three injured men died as a result of the crash.  On April 9, 2018, the U. S. District Court for the Central District of New Orleans entered a final judgment against Beal that permanently enjoins him from violating the antifraud provisions of Section 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933 and Section 10(b) of Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and orders him to pay a civil penalty of $5,000.  Without admitting or denying the allegations in the SEC complaint, Beal consented to the entry of a judgment permanently enjoining him from future violations of the federal securities laws, ordering him to be barred from serving as an officer or director of a public company, and imposing a five-year conduct-based injunction against him from participating in any future officer-director or director-level offering of a penny stock.  Beal also agreed to be restrained and restrained from appearing or practicing before the SEC as an attorney.  In a parallel action, the United States Attorney for New Orleans today announced that it filed a civil injunctive action and obtained an order appointing a receiver to oversee the investigation of the matter.  Among other things, the SEC charged Beal for his role in the scheme.
